Award.AwardTitle: 37th Conference on Stochastic Processes and their Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the participation of approximately twenty young U.S. researchers in the 37th Conference on Stochastic Processes and their Applications (SPA), to be held July 28-August 1, 2014, in Buenos Aires, Argentina. The meeting is organized under the auspices of the Bernoulli Society of the International Statistics Institute, and co-sponsored by the Institute of Mathematical Statistics. SPA conferences traditionally cover a wide range of current research topics in theoretical and applied probability, stochastic processes and statistical mechanics. The core of the present edition consists of scaling limits for random processes in discrete space, like interacting particle systems and models from Statistical Physics. Models such as exclusion processes, percolation and Ising give rise to continuum objects governed by PDEs or SPDEs, with the KPZ equation and the SLE emerging as the most relevant limiting objects. More applied topics as neuroscience and mathematic models for adaptive dynamics are also well represented, as well as Boltzmann equations, aging, hydrodynamic limits and spin glasses. In addition to plenary lectures by distinguished speakers there will time for young researchers, post docs and graduate students to present their results and interact with each other and with the experts.

Stochastic modeling has become ubiquitous these says. Realistic modeling is done at the smallest scale where it is easy to understand the physical process. But questions are often asked about what happens in a much larger scale. The transition involves a scaling limit and in this process certain universal behavior emerges. Different models at the micro level exhibit similar qualitative behavior at the macro scale. This notion of universality is important to understand from a mathematical point of view. The noise or randomness present at the micro level, while it is often suppressed in large scales, sometimes persists. When it does, the statistics of this noise shows a universal behavior, and it is important to understand what to expect in a given situation. There has been considerable progress recently along these lines and this has created a buzz. The conference will provide a forum for learning and exchanging ideas about them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Report on 

37th Conference on Stochastic Processes and their Applications

Buenos Aires, 28 July to 1 August 2014

 

 

          The 37th Conference on Stochastic Processes and their Applications (SPA) was held in  Buenos Aires, Argentina from July 28 to August 1, 2014. The meeting was co-organized by the University of Buenos Aires in partnership with the Bernoulli Society of the International Statistics Institute, the Institute of Mathematical Statistics, the Clay Mathematical Institute and the Instituto Nacional de Ciencia e Tecnologia Matemática, Brasil. 

 A total of 297 participants checked in, among which 186 researchers, 46 postdocs or recent PhD graduates, 52 PhD students, and 13 undergrad or master students. There were 16 plenary lectures and 120 talks carried out in 41 thematic sessions and 49 poster presentations. 

 

Participants came from all Continents, distributed as follows: France 45, Brazil 41, USA 36, Argentina 31, Germany 20, United Kingdom 20, Netherlands 14, Italy 12, Chile 11, Mexico 8, Canada 6, Israel 6, Japan 6, other European countries 25, other South-American countries 9, other continents 7.

 

The scientific program concentrated on scaling limits for spatial random processes. The Kardar-Parisi-Zhang equation played a central role, with several talks concentrating on various surface growth models, such as polymers, last passage percolation, asymmetric simple exclusion process, that fall in its universality class. Other talks discussed the convergence of statistical mechanics processes, percolation for instance,  to continuum limits governed by the stochastic Loewner evolution. More applied topics such as neuroscience and mathematical models for adaptive dynamics were also considered, as well as Boltzmann equations, aging, hydrodynamic limits and spin glasses.  

 

The plenary lecturers and the organizers of the sessions were distinguished scholars from all over the world, including many young scientists. The lectures gave an exiting review of many currently active research themes in probability. There was intense informal collaboration at faculty, postdoctoral and student levels between the participants. 

 

The meeting was extremely important to establish new contacts between the international recognized  America-based researchers and the probability groups of the other Countries, specially the Argentinian group who organized the meeting. 

 

 

 

The Lévy lecturer for 2014 was Martin Hairer, from the University of Warwick, UK,  and the IMS Medallion lecturer was David Nualart, from the University of Kansas, US. The list of plenary lecturers is the following. 

 

Anton Bovier, Bonn; Ivan Corwin, New York; Laszlo Erdös, Vienna; Antonio Galves, São Paulo; Christophe Garban, Lyon; Martin Hairer, Warwick (Lévy Lecture); Milton Jara, Rio de Janeiro; Gady Kozma, Weizmann Institute; Eyal Lubetzky, Microsoft; Sylvie Méléard, Palaiseau; David Nualart, Kansas (IMS Medallion Lecture); Felix Otto, Leipzig; Tomohiro Sasamoto, Chiba; Scott Sheffield, MIT; Fabio Toninelli, Lyon and Balint Tóth, Budapest

 

Links to the videos and the slides of the talks can be found in the program page of the meeting:  http://mate.dm.uba.ar/~probab/spa2014/program.html. 

 

The abstracts of the lectures, talks and posters are collected into this pdf booklet: http://mate.dm.uba.ar/~probab/spa2014/pdf/book.pdf

 

The local organizing committee for SPA 2014 was formed by

 

Inés Armendáriz, Pablo A. Ferrari, Pablo Groisman, Matthieu Jonckheere, Nora Muler and Leonardo T. Rolla (UBA),

 

The meeting was supported by Argentinian Funding Agencies, CONICET and ANPCyT, MinCyT, Secretaria de Políticas Universitarias from Universidad de Buenos Aires, the European Science Foundation, the International Mathematical Union, the National Science Foundation and INCTMat, Brazil. The funds obtained from those Agencies were used exclusively to pay local and/or travel  expenses of the participants. 

 

The grant of the National Science Foundation supported travel and lodging expenses of 22 America-based speakers and participants.
